text:
Apache shouldn't require python to build.  I don't care if its part of APR or
anything else.  This is a ridiculous requirement - that anyone who wants to
build or install Apache has to have a given interpreter installed on their system.
creator: jrhett@netconsonance.com
trawick@apache.org
text:
In general, it does not require Python to build, as most users do not need to
run the buildconf script (tar -xf then ./configure).

The theory is that the subset of APR users who need to run buildconf is
extremely small, so it was helpful to the folks implementing that portion of the
build to use something more maintainable.   What is the situation that puts you
in the subset which needs to run buildconf?

(discussions on the validity of that decision belong on the dev@apr mailing
list; but we can at least understand here why you need to run buildconf)

Sorry, valid point.  I was using the freebsd port, which has buildconf in the
Makefile.  I've opened PR# with them to find out why they were running buildconf
as part of the build process.

The patch I've just tested with (and works fine) is

--- Makefile_orig       Thu Jul  6 11:25:35 2006
+++ Makefile    Thu Jul  6 11:26:01 2006
@@ -22,7 +22,6 @@
 COMMENT?=      Version 2.2 of Apache web server with ${WITH_MPM:L} MPM.
 
 LIB_DEPENDS=   expat.6:${PORTSDIR}/textproc/expat2
-BUILD_DEPENDS= python:${PORTSDIR}/lang/python
 
 LATEST_LINK=   apache22
 
@@ -178,7 +177,6 @@
        @${INSTALL_DATA} ${WRKSRC}/NOTICE ${WRKSRC}/docs/manual
 
 pre-configure:
-       @cd ${WRKSRC}; ${SETENV} ${SCRIPTS_ENV} ./buildconf
 
 post-configure:
        @FTPUSERS=`${EGREP} -v '^#' /etc/ftpusers| ${TR} -s "\n" " "` ;\
creator: jrhett@netconsonance.com

text: That's the FreeBSD port Makefile, so marking INVALID.
creator: jorton@redhat.com
jrhett@netconsonance.com
text:
We don't know why they required buildconf.  Therefore I suggest waiting for
their response.  If there is a reason why it is required, the fix may have to
come from your side.

The maintainer claims that it simply doesn't work without rebuilding APR every
time.  This means that the idea of a "small subset" can't be true because it
includes the entire *BSD community.

You can see his comments here 
  http://www.freebsd.org/cgi/query-pr.cgi?pr=99848
creator: jrhett@netconsonance.com

text:
"it doesn't work, see the list archives" is not a useful bug report, marking
INVALID.  There were many fixes for use of out-of-tree APR/APR-util in the
2.2.0/APR 1.0 releases, it may be whatever historical problems they had have
been fixed by now.  If not then we need actual bug reports not just "it doesn't
work".
creator: jorton@redhat.com

text:
Look, I can't give you information that isn't provided to me.

In my experience, with my compilation environment, IT DOES WORK without Python
rebuilding apr.

So I'm ending up stuck in the middle of a disagreement between Apache developers
and FreeBSD developers on why this doesn't work.  Clement is being deliberately
obscure rather than providing details on why he thinks it doesn't work, so I
can't very well provide them to you now can I?

But frankly, I don't belong in the middle of this anyway.  Clement and you need
to put your heads together and figure this out.  Don't complain to me, complain
to him.
creator: jrhett@netconsonance.com
wrowe@apache.org
text:
This is a vendor packaging issue and NOT a sufficiently specific httpd/apr
  bug report.  Closing (for good, please).  If there is a specific issue that
  individuals must run buildconf due to an apr packaging issue, open a bug for
  that specific issue citing the exact problem.

  We are glad to hear of your success, and suggest you continue to obtain the
  ASF distributed sources and install those, as -those- distributions are
  maintained and bug reports reviewed here.
